[s 85] s 85 Examination on oath (cf Act No 52 1970, section 83; Act No 9 1973, section 70)

leg:heading.title: Examination on oath (cf Act No 52 1970, section 83; Act No 9 1973, section 70)

p.text: If a person is authorised by this Act or by rules of court, or by an order of the court, to take the examination of any person:
the examination is to be taken on oath, and
the oath may be administered by the person taking the examination or by a judicial officer of the court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 86] s 86 Orders (cf Act No 52 1970, section 21; Act No 9 1973, section 6; SCR Part 1, rule 11A)

leg:heading.title: Orders (cf Act No 52 1970, section 21; Act No 9 1973, section 6; SCR Part 1, rule 11A)

p.text: The power of the court to make orders in relation to proceedings, whether under this or any other Act or otherwise, includes the power:
to make orders by way of leave or direction, and
to make all or any orders on terms.
The power of the court to make orders on terms is taken to be a power to make orders on such terms and conditions as the court thinks fit.

Subject to this Act and to rules of court, the court may make any order that it has power to make either of its own motion or on the application of a party or any other person entitled to make such an application.
Nothing in this Act limits the operation of section 43 of the Interpretation Act 1987.

heading.title: Making orders subject to terms and conditions

p.text: This section permits a court to make any orders “on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit”, irrespective of whether or not any particular power conferred by the CPA or the UCPR expressly confers a power to make orders on “terms”. The power to impose terms and conditions obviously enlivens the general directions power in UCPR r 2.1 and attracts the discretionary principles provided for in CPA ss 56 . The terms that may be imposed include orders:
for the production or filing of documents or evidence (including witness statements or affidavits): s 61 and 62 CPA; UCPR rr 31.1 and 31.4;
imposing time limits (including self executing orders for dismissal for default): [36.16.75];
adjourning proceedings: s 66 CPA

for, or subject to, payment into court or by way of compensation to another party: Gorczynski v Holden [2008] NSWSC 334; BC200802606 (conditional orders made in the Local Court); noted at [22,010.80] .

Despite the breadth of the power to impose terms the permissible discretionary considerations in any particular case will depend on the nature of the power involved and the existence of a relevant relationship between the proper purposes of the exercise of the power and the nature of the term or condition imposed. For example, an application for an extension of time cannot be made subject to terms requiring the disclosure of privileged documents: Victoria v Davies (2003) 6 VLR 245 at [23]–[25]; [2003] VSCA 65; BC200302798 .

level.toc-caption: [s 86.10] Power to amend or repeal orders

heading.title: Power to amend or repeal orders

p.text: Section 43 of the Interpretation Act 1987 declares that a power to make orders under any Act or statutory rule includes a power to amend or repeal the order. However, the power is necessarily subject to the general principles relating to the finality of judgments and orders that determine proceedings: see [36.16.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 87] s 87 Protection against self-incrimination in relation to interlocutory matters (cf Act No 25 1995, sections 128 and 133)

leg:heading.title: Protection against self-incrimination in relation to interlocutory matters (cf Act No 25 1995, sections 128 and 133)

p.text: In this section:
has the same meaning as it has in the Evidence Act 1995.
includes both act and omission.
means conduct that, under:
the laws of New South Wales, or
the laws of any other State or Territory, or
the laws of the Commonwealth, or
the laws of a foreign country,
constitutes an offence or renders a person liable to a civil penalty.
means an interlocutory order requiring a person (other than a body corporate) to provide evidence to the court or to a party to a proceeding before the court.
means:
to provide an answer to a question or to produce a document or thing, or
to swear an affidavit, or
to file and serve an affidavit or a witness statement, or
to permit possession to be taken of a document or thing.
This section applies in circumstances in which:
an application is made for, or the court makes, an order for production against a person, and

the person objects to the making of such an order, or applies for the revocation of such an order, on the ground that the evidence required by the order may tend to prove that the person has engaged in culpable conduct.
This section does not apply in circumstances in which section 128A of the Evidence Act 1995 applies.
[subs (2A) insrt Act 46 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2[2.1], effective 1 January 2009]
If the court finds that there are reasonable grounds for the objection or application referred to in subsection (2)(b), the court is to inform the person, or the person’s legal representative:
that the person need not provide the evidence, and
that, if the person provides the evidence, the court will give a certificate under this section, and
of the effect of such a certificate.
If the person informs the court that he or she will provide the evidence, the court is to cause the person to be given a certificate under this section in respect of the evidence.

The court is also to cause a person to be given a certificate under this section if the court overrules an objection to the making of an order for production, or refuses an application for the revocation of such an order, but, after the evidence is provided, the court finds that there were reasonable grounds for the objection or application.
Despite anything in this section, the court may make an order for production if it is satisfied of the following:
that the evidence required by the order may tend to prove that the person has engaged in culpable conduct,
that the culpable conduct does not comprise conduct that, under:
the laws of any State or Territory (other than New South Wales), or
the laws of the Commonwealth, or
the laws of a foreign country,
constitutes an offence or renders a person liable to a civil penalty,
that the interests of justice require that the person provide the evidence.
If the court makes an order for production under subsection (6), it is to cause the person to be given a certificate under this section in respect of the evidence required by the order.
In any proceedings:
evidence provided by a person in respect of which a certificate under this section has been given, and
evidence of any information, document or thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person having provided such evidence,
cannot be used against the person. However, this does not apply to a criminal proceeding in respect of the falsity of the evidence.
If a question arises under this section relating to a document, the court may order that the document be produced to it and may inspect the document for the purpose of determining the question.

heading.title: Certificate precluding use of incriminating evidence

p.text: Section 87 applies to interlocutory orders (including directions to file affidavits and witness statements and orders for production). It complements Evidence Act 1995 ss 128 and 128A (which apply respectively to (i) evidence at the final hearing of proceedings, and (ii) interim preservation orders sought under UCPR Pt 25 ). The certificate procedure in CPA s 87(3) and (4) provides a mechanism for facilitating the disclosure of potentially incriminating evidence, and for compelling its disclosure where the incrimination only arises in relation to NSW law: see s 87(6) . They apply to any person required to “provide evidence” irrespective of their precise characterisation as witnesses, parties or third persons: In the Marriage of Atkinson (1997) 136 FLR 347 ; Versace v Monte [2001] FCA 1572; BC200107025 (Tamberlin J). If the privilege claim is made on reasonable grounds, the court must provide a certificate in relation to the otherwise privileged evidence, and the certificate precludes the evidence being subsequently used against the person: Bax Global (Australia) Pty Ltd v Evans (1999) 47 NSWLR 538; [1999] NSWSC 815; BC9904569 ; Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) (2002) 217 ALR 719; [2002] NSWSC 1192; BC200208077 at [4]–[8] .

level.toc-caption: [s 87.15] Reasonable grounds for the incrimination objection

heading.title: Reasonable grounds for the incrimination objection

p.text: The privilege against incrimination applies if there is a real and appreciable risk that the evidence may tend to establish the witness has committed a criminal offence: Sorby v Commonwealth (1983) 152 CLR 281 at 289; 46 ALR 237 at 241; BC8300067 per Gibbs CJ; R v Boys (1861) 1 B & S 311 (“reasonable ground to apprehend danger to the witness”); Ex parte P; Re Hamilton (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 397 at 399 (a real and appreciable risk). The privilege applies if the evidence might set in train a process which may lead to incrimination or may lead to the discovery of real evidence of an incriminating nature: Sorby v Commonwealth (1983) 152 CLR 281; 46 ALR 237; BC8300067 per Gibbs CJ; Mason, Wilson and Dawson JJ. The privilege is capable of applying even where the witness has made prior out of court admissions: Accident Insurance Mutual Holdings Ltd v McFadden (1993) 31 NSWLR 412 .

The court must be satisfied objectively on the material before it that there are reasonable grounds to establish a risk of incrimination, before the privilege can be claimed: R v Boyes (1861) 1 B & S 311 at 329–30; 121 ER 730 at 738; Triplex Safety Glass Co Ltd v Lancegaye Safety Glass (1934) Ltd [1939] 2 KB 395 at 404; Jackson v Gamble [1983] VR 552 at 556; Controlled Consultants Pty Ltd v Cmr for Corporate Affairs (Vic) [1984] VR 137 at 151; (1983) 8 ACLR 458 ; National Assn of Operative Plasterers and Smithies [1906] AC 434 at 437 . A mere apprehension of, or belief in, the possibility of legal peril is insufficient to invoke the privilege: R v Boyes (1861) 1 B & S 311; 121 ER 730; Hammond v Commonwealth (1982) 152 CLR 188; 42 ALR 327 at 334; BC8200099 .

The privilege applies by reference to the incriminating nature of the conduct disclosed by the evidence, rather than to the probability of actual prosecution: Saffron v FCT (1992) 109 ALR 695; 92 ATC 4432 . The risk of incrimination is not assessed by considering whether prosecutors are likely to be soft-hearted or a jury indulgent: Triplex Safety Glass Co Ltd , above at 407), nor by reference to the number of prosecutions launched in respect of the particular act: Evans v Staunton [1958] Qd R 96 at 110 and see Korp v Egg & Egg Pulp Marketing Board [1964] VR 563 at 569–70 . If there is apparent substance to the basis for the claim the privilege tends to be applied, in relation to particular questions or documents, in favour of the witness: Triplex Safety Glass Co Ltd v Lancegaye Safety Glass (1934) Ltd , above; Re Hamilton; Ex parte P (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 397 at 399 . Apart from abridgement by statute the privilege against incrimination is of general application. It is a universal right to which the common law does not permit exceptions: Reid v Howard (1995) 184 CLR 1; 131 ALR 609 .

The application of the privilege may be excluded, in particular legislation, either expressly or by necessary implication. CPA s 87 and Evidence Act ss 128 and 128A provide obvious examples of express exclusions. Apart from explicit provisions of that kind, a statute will not be construed as excluding the privilege unless an intention to do so clearly appears: Sorby v Commonwealth (1983) 152 CLR 281; 46 ALR 237 ; Hammond v Commonwealth (1982) 152 CLR 188; 42 ALR 327 ; Pyneboard Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 152 CLR 328; 45 ALR 609 ; Commissioners of Customs & Excise v Ingram [1948] 1 All ER 927 ; Commissioners of Customs & Excise v Ingram [1949] 1 All ER 896 . Where the privilege has been abrogated, it is not unusual to find in the legislation an attempt to provide some protection to a witness by providing that their answers may not be used in evidence in other proceedings. However the converse proposition does not automatically follow, and the presence of such a provision in legislation does not, of itself, reveal a clear intention that the privilege is intended to be abrogated: Sorby v Commonwealth , above at 253. When the ground upon which the privilege is asserted is that of exposure to a civil liability rather than a criminal conviction, it may be easier to identify an intention to exclude the privilege in the relevant statutory provisions: Price v McCabe [1985] 2 Qd R 510; (1984) 55 ALR 319 .

This term is defined in the Evidence Act 1995 to include any penalty arising in non-criminal proceedings under Australian or foreign law. The expression has the same meaning in the definition of “privileged information” for the purpose of the UCPR: see CPA s 87(1) . The concept of a “civil penalty” is concerned with penalties recoverable under a statute as distinct from sums recoverable under a contract and as distinct also from sums, in the nature of compensation, that may be recoverable by virtue of a specific statutory provision: Adams v Batley (1887) 18 QBD 625 (statutory penalty for infringement of a copyright); Colne Valley Water Co v Watford and St Albans Gas Co [1948] 1 KB 500 (penalties for pollution of water supply). Proceedings for civil penalties include:
disciplinary proceedings involving demotion or dismissal: Police Service Board v Morris (1985) 156 CLR 397; 58 ALR 1 ;

proceedings to impose or recover fines: Pyneboard Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 152 CLR 328; 45 ALR 609 ; Birrell v Australian National Airlines Commission (1984) 1 FCR 526; 55 ALR 211 ; and

disqualification under ss 206C and 206E of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth): Rich v Australian Securities and Investments Commission (2004) 209 ALR 271; 50 ACSR 242; [2004] HCA 42; BC200405817 ; compare Mayor of Derby v Derbyshire County Council [1897] AC 550 at 552 ; Refrigerated Express Lines (A’asia) Pty Ltd v Australian Meat and Livestock Corp (1979) 42 FLR 204 ; Seddon v Commercial Salt Co [1925] Ch 187 ; Pyneboard Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 152 CLR 328 at 335–6; 45 ALR 609 .

The expression “civil penalty” probably includes proceedings brought to establish forfeiture, for example, forfeiture of a lease. In these proceedings, the sole question is whether forfeiture has taken place and discovery and interrogatories cannot be obtained: Earl of Mexborough v Whitwood Urban District Council [1897] 2 QB 111 ; WM Collins and Sons Pty Ltd v T & T Mining Corp Pty Ltd [1971] Qd R 427 . Proceedings for an order under s 70 of the Supreme Court Act 1970, which substitutes injunctive and declaratory relief for the former writ of quo warranto, are analogous to proceedings for the forfeiture of land and discovery and interrogatories will not ordinarily be ordered against a defendant: Taylor v Carmichael [1984] 1 NSWLR 421 .

level.toc-caption: [s 87.30] Disclosure ordered in the “interests of justice”

heading.title: Disclosure ordered in the “interests of justice”

p.text: Whether the interests of justice require disclosure of information that would otherwise tend to establish “culpable conduct” depends on the apparent materiality of the information to, and its probable reliability in aiding, the proper determination of the issues in dispute in the proceedings: Versace v Monte [2001] FCA 1572; BC200107025 at [11] per Tamberlin J. The greater the capacity of the information to play a significant part in the proper resolution of the proceedings, the more its disclosure is required in the furtherance of the interests of justice: Strata Consolidated (Aust) Pty Ltd v Bradshaw (NSWSC, 18 March 1996, unreported); R v Fowler (NSWSC, Dowd J, 6 May 1997, unreported). The information may be material if it is directly relevant to the existence or extent of property that is the subject of the proceedings: In the Marriage of Atkinson (1997) 136 FLR 347 (information about a spouse’s income in property settlement proceedings); Kang-Kem v Paine [2003] NSWSC 916; BC200306039 at [8] (dispute as to whether a business was operated as a partnership). Evidence may be material even where it relates principally to the credibility of a witness: Cureton v Blackshaw Services Pty Ltd [2002] NSWCA 187; BC200203514 . But the interests of justice do not require disclosure of unreliable evidence: R v Collisson (2003) 139 A Crim R 389; [2003] NSWCCA 212; BC200304289 (inherently unreliable evidence of an accomplice, disclosure not required).

Section 187 of the Evidence Act 1995 provides that the privilege against self-incrimination is not available to bodies corporate. Earlier the High Court decided in Environment Protection Authority v Caltex Refining Co Pty Ltd (1993) 178 CLR 477; 118 ALR 392 that the privilege against incrimination does not apply to corporations. In Trade Practices Commission v Abbco Ice Works Pty Ltd (1994) 52 FCR 96; 123 ALR 503 , it was held that the privilege against exposure to civil penalty was not available to a corporation. Section 87 of the CPA is similarly inapplicable to corporations. The section applies where the court makes an “order for production”, but that term is defined in s 87(1) as excluding orders directed to corporations.

If a trial of proceedings has commenced before a judicial officer and he or she is unable to continue the trial or give judgment in the proceedings, by reason of death, resignation or incapacity, the senior judicial officer of the relevant court may nominate some other judicial officer of that court as the judicial officer before whom the proceedings are to be listed for trial.
In this section, a reference to a trial of proceedings includes a reference to a trial of one or more questions in the proceedings.
Legislation cited in [s 88.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The term “senior judicial officer of the relevant court” is not governed by any statutory definition. It is likely, as a consequence of the definition of “judicial officer” in CPA s 3 and the Judicial Officers Act 1986 s 3, to refer to the most senior officer of the relevant court, rather than to the senior officer within any divisions of the court. Consequently, in the Supreme Court the expression refers to the Chief Justice: Starr-Diamond v Diamond [2012] NSWSC 675; BC201204320 at [34] . In courts such as the District Court and the Land and Environment Court, the expression refers to the Chief Judge of the Court: Lowe v Pascoe [2012] NSWSC 151; BC201201320 at [87] .

level.toc-caption: [s 88.10] Fresh trial of part heard proceedings

heading.title: Fresh trial of part heard proceedings

p.text: The ordinary position is that the judge who constitutes the court for the purpose of hearing proceedings must continue with the proceedings to the conclusion of the hearing, and their determination by a final judgment or order. This ordinary position is subject to some qualifications that potentially apply (i) where incapacity arises after the court has prepared reasons for judgment, (ii) if the incapacity only affects the minority of the officers who constitute the court, or (iii) where the undetermined matter only concerns an ancillary issue in the proceedings: see Orr v Holmes (1948) 76 CLR 632 at 637–8; 22 ALJR 283; BC4800240 ; and the notes to SCA s 40.10. Apart from these situations, and any statutory modification similar to that made in the present section, part heard proceedings could only be regularly determined by a differently constituted court where the parties consented to that court taking into account the earlier evidence in the proceedings: see Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129 at 136–7; [1953] ALR 528; (1953) 27 ALJR 120; BC5300600 ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 3) (1986) 6 NSWLR 642 ; and see SCA s 40.10.

level.toc-caption: [s 88.15] Directions about the “trial” of part heard proceedings

heading.title: Directions about the “trial” of part heard proceedings

p.text: The present section permits the senior judicial officer to determine the constitution of the court for the purpose of the further (fresh) trial of part heard proceedings. However, the actual procedures that will apply to the further (or fresh) trial are to be determined by the court constituted to conduct the further hearing: Lowe v Pascoe [2012] NSWSC 151; BC201201320 at [88] and [96] ; Starr-Diamond v Diamond [2012] NSWSC 675; BC201204320 at [33] and [34]: see further [s 89.5] .
If:
any proceedings have been listed for trial pursuant to section 88 , or
an appellate court has made an order for a fresh trial generally (being an order given on an appeal after a trial of any proceedings), or
a judicial officer before whom a trial of any proceedings has commenced has discharged himself or herself from the trial without having given judgment in the proceedings,
the court may give such directions as it thinks fit as to the evidence to be used in the fresh trial.
In particular, the court may give either or both of the following directions:
a direction that all or any part of the evidence given at the previous trial is to be taken to be evidence in the fresh trial without the need for the witnesses to be recalled,
a direction that all or any of the witnesses are to be recalled for examination or cross-examination, or both, either generally or as to a particular question or questions in the proceedings.
In subsection (1) , a reference to a trial of proceedings includes a reference to a trial of one or more questions in the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [s 89.5] Directions about the “trial” of part heard proceedings

heading.title: Directions about the “trial” of part heard proceedings

p.text: The present section complements CPA s 88 and confers a general discretionary power to determine the procedure that will apply to the “fresh” trial of any proceedings to which CPA s 89(1) applies. The breadth of the power is highlighted by the express permission for the court to receive “all or any part” of the previous trial evidence with, or without, requiring any further examination of the relevant witnesses (either generally or in relation to particular questions: see CPA s 89(2)). The power must be exercised conformably with the “overriding purpose” in CPA s 56, and with an awareness of the reasons for the commonly expressed reservations about the potential undesirability of relying on evidence that was given at an earlier stage of the proceedings: see generally the notes to SCA s 40.10; Lowe v Pascoe [2012] NSWSC 151; BC201201320 at [95]–[96] ; Starr-Diamond v Diamond [2012] NSWSC 675; BC201204320 at [33] and [34].
